According to [readers of the *New York Times*](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/06/movies/readers-favorite-1999-movies.html), the top four movies of 1999 were *The Matrix*, *Fight Club*, *Office Space*, and *American Beauty*. I love this selection because I think they‚Äôre all basically the same movie, starring basically one character:\
![](images/drone-comp.png){width="650"}

The movie goes like this:

*An office schlub encounters a mythical stranger who teaches him that rules of reality are optional. He decides to stop playing along and immediately becomes cool, popular, and powerful: a middle-aged* ubermensch*. With his newfound powers he attempts to throw off the shackles of society and achieve his true desires, pitting him against powerful forces that fear his liberation.*¬†

Let‚Äôs start with *Office Space*, the first to come out and in many ways the template for the microgenre.

When we meet our protagonist, he‚Äôs stuck in traffic. Look at the desperation in his eyes:

![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXe27G-usdlhhlEeYqpN9OBHtPYxQRNBoH1jpEXWuXTw03nQ-CNgBsjYjteLCnnxAZTPDiR4TFC5PochU75A_vqk5DIAwt9na0HfOXaUgVXmMjqfGQGJDNJXaxg6UGWXZvuUBz-0iuX80qNX8TQHmVhK_g0L?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

We learn about the drudgery of Peter‚Äôs life. He hates his job and his boss, Lumbergh. He thinks his girlfriend is cheating on him, and his friends agree. He has a crush on Joana, a local waitress (Jennifer Aniston), but he‚Äôs too chicken to ask her out. ‚ÄúEvery single day that you see me, that‚Äôs on the worst day of my life,‚Äù Peter tells a hypnotherapist.¬†

![*Our mythical stranger, who looks like a wizard gone to seed.*](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXd-fNcoi_WSPSYXIk5Dg8HxE8KRK_fJNLbM1t-1LkoBdS5hLUxCKHC2ZKo8UXFuPEu4KfxBHH8LCmlvrp8R6BB01J1Yby8ESeN0R_T5rfnDpflSWGnMH4Vu_K0F1ixLJlc_32vXNc0F9I_EXOOjAw7J0iKU?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

‚ÄúIs there any way that you could sorta, just zonk me out, so I don‚Äôt know that I‚Äôm at work, in here?‚Äù he asks. The therapist can‚Äôt do that, but he does ask Peter to try to relax, to ‚Äúslip deeper and deeper into a state of complete relaxation...Now when I count backwards from three...your worries, cares and inhibitions will be gone. And you will remain in that state until I snap my fingers.‚Äù But our mythical stranger dies suddenly and never snaps his fingers. All of Peter‚Äôs worries, cares, and inhibitions are gone.

The next 20 minutes of the movie are sublime. First, Peter sleeps the day away and hangs up on his horrible girlfriend. He rolls in late to work, wearing much cooler outfits, where he plays Tetris, guts a fish on his desk, and generally kicks back.

![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXek2wB9xHAjmnBbZGIg88xO17dSVG3HQsah1K91E6anaq5-tlDG3EZg2F3c_5Ax_gBS_jdhyAzWPk8wVsMNBzrGGJfz87SCBNfnXpgCeNws9HpnUlNveePt7skjANUgiAIWfuJ7UuguM-mFK52sw6-NgIs?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

He asks Joana out and wins her over with his open-hearted honesty. He then talks to two downsizing consultants at his company in [one of the most iconic scenes of 1990s cinema](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OwfNjGxa_D4).

Just like Joana, they‚Äôre completely taken with Peter, calling him a ‚Äústraight-shooter with upper management written all over him.‚Äù Most importantly, his new status with the consultants causes him to either ignore or dominate Lumbergh.

So what will Peter do with his newfound power? At first, it seems like all he‚Äôll do is make more money, do less work, and watch Kung Fu movies with the [most beautiful person on earth 2004](https://people.com/celebrity/most-beautiful-people-2004/): sweet! But then he learns that his friends Samir and Michael are about to get laid off, and he hatches a plan to get back at the company. The three of them plant a virus designed to steal small sums from a [huge number of routine transactions and thereby enrich themselves](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yZjCQ3T5yXo).

This is where the movie loses me because I don‚Äôt care about Peter‚Äôs getting one over on the company. ‚ÄúInitech is an evil corporation,‚Äù he tells Joana, but we don‚Äôt see a lot of evidence of that. Sure, the way Lumbergh treats Milton is completely unethical, but Milton is perfectly capable of striking back (and does so spectacularly). His friends quickly find other jobs.¬†

No, what‚Äôs happening here is that even though Peter has lost all his worries, cares, and inhibitions, his imagination is still profoundly limited. He breaks things off with Joana when he thinks she dated Lumbergh once upon a time, and the scene where Peter dreams of the two of them together is [the most sexually alive in the movie](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2sedeU6YZN4). We see that Peter‚Äôs job is his life. His newfound powers as a liberated man have nowhere to go because he can‚Äôt imagine other possible selves. He‚Äôs obsessed with a dominance contest with Lumbergh, a man who, yes, drives a Porsche, but also has to work weekends and celebrate his birthday with people who despise him.¬†

Peter does eventually move on. At the movie‚Äôs end, He‚Äôs working construction with his neighbor Lawrence, and if he‚Äôs not the same ecstatic person he was when he first achieved enlightenment, he at least seems content. Initech is no longer his entire world, and although he is literally cleaning up its ashes when we last see him, he seems happy with his little life.

\*\*\*

Contrast this with *Fight Club*, whose protagonist has, to put it lightly, a more active imagination.

Our hero (‚ÄòThe narrator‚Äô) is beset by insomnia and trying to fill the void with mindless consumerism and support groups for diseases he doesn‚Äôt have.

![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXejzerNirerTTa-wbL2OB27lv_a3QyEmuAodmu8zs4dz-8TZJj0Ai0gVz_RPph5gz92Dzwyu7i_7SEeohJe_f63gQi6MO8iesgWGKoXN5M1HFSC09m_vgCvZIWT3TMM5kIdn3N7wE6vralEzx8oBYFTlIc?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

He goes where his boss tells him and translates life and death into bottom line calculations for an unethical car company. Finally he wakes up from a reverie about a plane crash and meets his mythical stranger: Tyler Durden, played by [People‚Äôs Sexiest Man Alive 2000](https://people.com/celebrity/all-the-sexiest-man-alive-covers/) as a vision of violent masculinity.

![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXc6JUe2FNh2NMMQStw2NEqcyZ-zhNXKYEOcTllQMMrrrZqg3eNVKZaZejRQ_w1NcV6ZThI4_yaHzju0YvxqD0jeCk0e_Hs6pOX54c8j-3ke5OYleQ3-fWqhIMnajBZ2RyscaOEMJv7V_yxMUuAHIZDSm4Wg?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

The narrator then loses everything in a house fire and seeks out Tyler, who consoles him: ‚Äúthe things you own end up owning you. But do what you like man.‚Äù Tyler then makes a request: ‚ÄúI want you to hit me as hard as you can.‚Äù One thing leads to another and soon they‚Äôre living together in squalor and hosting a fight club. It‚Äôs a complete rejection of The narrator‚Äôs previous docile, consumerist life, and it comes with numerous benefits.

It helps our hero turn the volume down on his stupid, sneering boss.

![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXd1Fu1cEK_LQGbTOdlYZrkgZltbY577bESWreAXC9GMpw2aVCqeb1YXX8HILQ_NDxTGytU5lEWKNM_OKQuwW5S43ZlgYdq1O_cfnzxSKrHGk2HAzmgIQ3Ch0zHr-xpWHPHSK3VYCMjjUeWLXc1s5oLVVMGa?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

He finds emotional equanimity and (as far as we know) starts being able to sleep better. He stops going to support groups. He and Tyler [walk into a bar like they own the place](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BZrNk0izwy4). ‚ÄúYou weren‚Äôt alive anywhere like you were alive there,‚Äù he says. We watch the club bring meaning and camaraderie to its participants‚Äô otherwise empty, unsatisfying lives.

The narrator then [blackmails his boss by beating himself up.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6pJC0FLA3Sk) This total rejection of the rules of the game both gets him what he wants ‚Äî a modest salary without having to work, the Gen X dream ‚Äî and establishes that he, the injured mess, is in fact socially dominant.

Eventually Tyler starts to direct the club‚Äôs misery and rage into random acts of violence, and then not-so-random acts designed to erase the debt record. Finally we learn that Tyler is The narrator‚Äôs night-time personality, which causes The narrator to shoot himself, killing Tyler but not himself (??), and then we watch some buildings blow up. The end.

When I rewatched this movie, the main thing that stood out was how right wing its politics are. The anti-capitalist veneer coded it left 25 years ago, but these guys‚Äô general rage, their impulse to destroy, and their harnessing of male lostness for political ends all seem [very](https://x.com/varadmehta/status/1832934525652914448) [trump-y](https://x.com/balajis/status/1751195368417829213?lang=en). Incels have [taken notice](https://www.theguardian.com/film/2023/oct/27/david-fincher-on-hitmen-incels-and-spider-mans-dumb-origin-story). David Fincher despairs of this, saying: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs impossible for me to imagine that people don‚Äôt understand that Tyler Durden is a negative influence‚Ä¶People who can‚Äôt understand that, I don‚Äôt know how to respond and I don‚Äôt know how to help them.‚Äù To which I would say, it‚Äôs your movie that made Tyler out to be cool and sexy and socially dominant. It‚Äôs your camera that ogles his blood-spattered body. You can‚Äôt imagine Tyler trying to storm the capitol, but the men in his orbit? Absolutely. ‚ÄúWe have no Great War,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúNo Great Depression. Our Great War‚Äôs a spiritual war‚Ä¶ our Great Depression is our lives.‚Äù This movie‚Äôs basic premise is that war would have been a good answer to these men‚Äôs problems, but absent that, they need to start just blowing stuff up. Pardon me for not finding that amenable.¬†

Which brings us naturally to The Matrix.

The Matrix was the first R-rated movie I saw in a theater, and to this day I think it absolutely rules. Way back in the early 2000s, its influence was everywhere: a [video game franchise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Payne) with bullet time as a central play mechanic and [dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underworld_(2003_film)) [fantasy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%86on_Flux_(film))/[sci-fi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultraviolet_(film)) [movies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equilibrium_(film)) with distinct color schemes and elaborately superhuman fight scenes. But what sticks out to me nowadays, as a friend recently said, is how we ever could have thought it was anything besides a trans metaphor.

When we first meet Thomas Anderson, he‚Äôs asleep at his desk. He looks unwell.

![](images/neo-asleep.png){width="650"}

He stays out too late at a club, and the next morning it's time for his [routine workplace humiliation](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c_Ot1OEfk9I).

![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXeYVSH0yBVmOOlS7zia00R-J530hP6_35xpF5Qd5CyDhdv_X_--ll8vnoa7l_wfPxRb3i8dc65aDxlu-BcSFBFHGltOwFT6hxzfVPI1XczOtTtMkW4wiC0R2nFrc2IWZLdXeuMtgRgav2zgAs6xMJwBxeZp?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

Soon after, we meet the mythical stranger, Morpheus,

![](images/morpheus.png){width="650"}

and [his offer of a way out](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zE7PKRjrid4).

I‚Äôd call this the most famous, recreated, parodied, and memed scene in the past 50 years of movies. But to me, the key difference between this scene and the other mysterious stranger scenes in the microgenre is that our protagonist chooses to be liberated. Peter and The narrator (and Lester Burnham, as we‚Äôll see) all have their life-changing encounter by chance. Peter wakes up and wants to fight a single company. The narrator just wants to feel alive. But the hero of The Matrix has enough agency to choose his fight. His enemy is reality itself, or more specifically the reality of gender. Consider:

-   After being red-pilled, our hero wakes up desexed in an egg. ![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXcq-FY_f2Oh5vXlaazrkYYLtxJJkyAoQ_hUoBvB-FuI3sHif8sZ-pAxVc7YG9kPH2PSOoBfQ8Lp-UlGjGWLRgdNjLYAuhE18zh1elFp1PuKJGUZhTQsGgQkkMhlAEEpevO9GwI5q2TdabQ01QuY7kWtIgup?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

-   He undergoes a quick surgery from a friendly robot doctor.![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXe2uzW-6oj45cFiy1vZJ4yQ1WIdpq8eJTDCAXfdttV2dlhO-BkchfTeC7O1gS69ha_8IIDYG_yTyu5wa9lvAhkDfgrlYGIJh9GRBopEN8oHNUB1PJJyGIqeiGP93jFlxP1gkyN6KcWzORyTy7zGBJUz8FqF?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

-   He then gets rescued by a band of merry pirates who basically all wear the same clothes...

![](images/ship-comp.png){width="650"}

-   One of whom is named Switch! (Apparently Switch was [intended](https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-53692435) to ‚Äúbe a man in the real world and then a woman in the Matrix.‚Äù)

-   Once he‚Äôs with his chosen family ‚Äî because, again, he made a conscious choice ‚Äî everyone of course calls the protagonist by his chosen name: Neo. For the rest of the movie, the only people who deadname Neo are agents of The Matrix. During the movie‚Äôs climax, when he‚Äôs fighting [Agent Elrond](https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0915989/), Neo heroically [refuses to be called Mr. Anderson (emphasis on Mister)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RoIolWbvFRg).

At the film‚Äôs end, Neo tells the agents that he‚Äôs ‚Äú[going to show these people what you don‚Äôt want them to see](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ocIDan61pc). I‚Äôm going to show them a world‚Ä¶without rules or controls, without borders or boundaries. A world where anything is possible. Where we go from there is a choice I leave to you.‚Äù For a movie where characters spend a lot of time killing people, this is quite the conciliatory message! Neo wants to live in harmony with everyone, his former oppressors included. This is really what makes *The Matrix* the best movie of the year: Underneath the gun-fu, it has a heart of gold.

\*\*\*

The same can‚Äôt be said, I‚Äôm afraid, for *American Beauty*.

I was surprised to see it on the *Times* list. Although I loved it in high school, today I think that if you traveled back in time to make a movie that was designed to age badly, you couldn‚Äôt do much better than *American Beauty*. It is, quite simply, an [Oscar-winning](https://uproxx.com/movies/american-beauty-20th-anniversary-analysis/) movie about Kevin Spacey throwing off the shackles of society to pursue his one true goal of seducing a teenager. It‚Äôs almost comically on the nose as a glamorization of ‚ÄúMale Horniness is Good Actually,‚Äù and [exactly the kind of enabling bullshit](https://web.archive.org/web/20221011162759/https://variety.com/2022/film/news/kevin-spacey-accuser-anthony-rapp-watching-american-beauty-trial-1235399148/) that facilitated Kevin Spacey‚Äôs predatory behavior for decades.

The movie opens on Thora Birch complaining about her dad and asking an unseen interlocutor to kill him. We then meet the dad. His name is Lester Burnham. He‚Äôs 42 years old, and in less than a year, he tells us, he‚Äôll be dead. ‚ÄúIn a way,‚Äù Lester narrates, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dead already.‚Äù\

![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXeoeajF0AqiSWQz_QGebbQ27_NXDTMbOJ29FptdjP9bjNlte4qZe9jmwktOVLKGHUM33-fBtY7wOPMlIyhAdkDti_Dy-gLqQl89Wck1BBr6QIQgZmb8FxCNauWJycR1vkzpUH_g-aS54dD-4DfW7CZz_6n0?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

We watch him masturbate in the shower. We learn that his wife and daughter ‚Äúthink I‚Äôm this gigantic loser. And they‚Äôre right. I have lost something. I‚Äôm not exactly sure what it is, but I know I didn‚Äôt always feel this‚Ä¶ sedated. But you know what, it‚Äôs never too late to get it back.‚Äù OK Lester, I‚Äôm with you so far!

Next it‚Äôs time for the *de rigeur* workplace humiliation scene in the microgenre. Brad Dupree, who‚Äôs obviously a total yuppie jerk, calls Lester into his office to talk about cost-cutting. He asks Lester to write a job description for management.

![*Brad is way less fun than the Bobs.*](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXf59DriBtY54f2F96I2cx1t8y-UZjV06yjhCGv8glxDMi5pJ75QRcuFUtRQof5V8_-0RxHr48olFD1LqkqkocRA9EuWZDuPoCiqLOPCM5BNqrqTsPJ8i43m2g-edj18BQPRtxL6CNf_BwZnSYxnknLMcgA?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

Lester balks at this, but enlightenment is around the corner. When he goes to see his daughter cheerlead, he has a "mythical encounter' (üòâ üòâ ) with her friend and teammate Angela, first imagining her dancing, and then envisioning her covered in roses and smiling, just for Lester because he's such a special boy.

![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXdVAtSrKUWAGU3n7kQLRvg3GqcA0UeaP9BDUFNFV6Q_DNuF6uI4EqbHi4eXIRFBW8cCLPg_gf1TOpf4Vf_PASHb7smORdGD-ib4JIRDDjhPFiQRafkx0WNVrEjGjCdEcTix7NTn6tIMWpEwyvVE5eutCJO1?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ){width="650"}

(Stepping outside the movie for a second, actress Mena Suvari was 19-20 when she filmed these scenes, so it‚Äôs a little less pervy than Lester‚Äôs diegetic infatuation. But it‚Äôs certainly in the same creepy ballpark. Today these scenes remind me uncomfortably of Britney Spears‚Äôs 1999 Rolling Stone cover, [shot when she was 17](https://chicagomaroon.com/28407/arts/weve-never-really-known-britney-spears/).)

After Lester‚Äôs totally imagined encounter with Angela, he feels like he's "[just now waking up](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g7NXm8YCPDw)" from a coma, so he decides to stop being a schlub and become cool. ("Spectacular!" he says.) He buys an awesome car, starts smoking weed, and joins his cool gay neighbors for jogs. ‚ÄúI want to look good naked!‚Äù he says. This is now the animating goal of his life, and it‚Äôs entirely so he can sleep with Angela; when she later asks him what he wants, he replies: ‚ÄúAre you kidding? I want you. I've wanted you since the first moment I saw you. You are the most beautiful thing I have ever seen.‚Äù (The word ‚Äòthing‚Äô is apt, from Lester‚Äôs point of view.)

![](https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXc6LWTPtQ5emAPKSkWElHviYkUYwzy3ndVVTDr_XemIefCzI4ATDkN4ccrRpIghMenGjFEAUQAk88c2Wzmvz_MvkUoYyGDqcYXM60vOB7gZ0cwlQom4toECmehUjCfyzGTDZzV60r9RcCfnVhKXO_yOY9DM?key=YtWVjgDJ7238lJOn_6LEFQ)

*For some reason he has to work out naked too.*

Society, as embodied by his shrew of a wife Carolyn ‚Äî wonderfully portrayed by Annette Benning, woefully underwritten by Alan Ball ‚Äî tells him: ‚Äúyou won‚Äôt get away with this!‚Äù ‚Äú[That‚Äôs. What. You. Think!](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NL0yymwDFz8)‚Äù Lester responds, in between bench press reps. He then blackmails his company for the same thing The narrator wanted ‚Äî severance of ‚Äúone year‚Äôs pay *with* benefits‚Äù ‚Äî and when he doesn‚Äôt have enough ammunition to get the job done, he [throws in an offer to accuse poor Brad of sexual harassment](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hJVXg1AHQTY).¬†

Two things stand out about this scene. The first is that Lester asks Brad if he can prove that Brad didn‚Äôt offer to save Lester‚Äôs job if Lester let Brad go down on him; in their imaginary tryst, Lester still has dominance. Second, when Brad calls him out for his disgusting behavior, Lester says: ‚ÄúNope. I‚Äôm just an ordinary guy with nothing to lose.‚Äù Nothing to lose, except, I don‚Äôt know, income for your family? Carolyn and Jane don‚Äôt seem to cross his mind at all. Post-enlightenment, Lester is a psychopath. Or maybe he always was.

Once Lester gets fit, Angela comes on to him, and right before they‚Äôre about to have sex in the family living room ‚Äî with his daughter upstairs and his wife soon to come home ‚Äî he calls it off when she blurts out that she‚Äôs a virgin. Then Lester gets shot and killed by his neighbor because he‚Äôs a repressed homosexual or something. But if Chris Cooper hadn‚Äôt done it, his daughter‚Äôs boyfriend, Carolyn, and Jane all seemed keen on getting the job done. Once you become liberated, this movie says, everyone wants to kill you.

It also goes out of its way to make Lester sympathetic. As his journey concludes, he says: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm great. I‚Äôm great.‚Äù In his closing monologue, he tells us that ‚Äúit‚Äôs hard to stay mad when there‚Äôs so much beauty in the world.‚Äù We‚Äôve watch a few scenes of Lester trying to connect with Jane, and his final thoughts are about her and Carolyn. But the last real conversation he has with Jane, after she calls his behavior with Angela disgusting, ends with: ‚Äúyou better watch yourself Jane, or you‚Äôre going to turn into a real bitch just like your mother!‚Äù He says this because he is a bad man. He is the film‚Äôs [villain](https://villains.fandom.com/wiki/Lester_Burnham). The essential problem with *American Beauty* is that it doesn‚Äôt know that.

And given the milieu, that almost makes sense. Something about 1999 made it a very fruitful year to tell stories about middle aged white guys throwing off their middle class shackles. That same millieu let viewers look past the question of what these guys are freeing themselves *for ‚Äî* the throwing off is the point. The hero undergoes what Arthur Chu calls, in a closely related essay, a ‚Äú[Hollywoodized Buddhist](https://www.thedailybeast.com/complaining-like-its-1999-fight-club-american-beauty-and-the-revolt-of-the-cubicle-drone)‚Äù conversion where he learns ‚Äúthat material comfort isn‚Äôt everything and that freeing ourselves from attachments to material things like jobs and mortgages is the key to true enlightenment and happiness.‚Äù¬†

But the jigsaw piece that won‚Äôt fit here is that Lester has not at all given up material things. Right after he quits, he buys a 1970 Pontiac Firebird. ‚ÄúThe car I've always wanted and now I have it. I rule!‚Äù And, as he tells us, he also sees Angela as a thing. What Lester rejects is doing things for others rather than doing things for himself. Supporting the family, or being a good father to his daughter, doesn‚Äôt spark joy. Smoking weed and trying to sleep with a teenager does. It‚Äôs as simple as that.

\*\*\*

Putting these movies all together, what do we get?

First, the fortunes of software engineers have changed a lot. Neo and Peter live in crappy apartments and have to be at their desk precisely at 9 and wear a suit. At least in the 2010s, [things](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/22/technology/artificial-intelligence-experts-salaries.html) [were](https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/16/business/at-google-a-place-to-work-and-play.html) [pretty](https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/02/02/google-meta-layoffs-sanfrancisco/) [different](https://www.ibtimes.co.uk/how-get-paid-doing-nothing-inside-silicon-valleys-controversial-rest-vest-culture-1633884).

More broadly, we see a lot of angst about displacement and automation. Each movie portrays an office as just another factory where the people are the cogs. As one of the Bobs puts it in *Office Space*, the plan for laid off workers is to ‚Äúbring in some entry-level graduates, farm some work out to Singapore, that's the usual deal.‚Äù We are, in Tyler's words, "slaves with white collars," raised to think we're special but in fact easily replaceable.

We also have a common thread of betas becoming alphas. Notice how, in the portraits at the beginning of this essay, three of four men are glancing down, avoiding eye contact (The narrator is looking at nothing in particular behind his insomnia.) The narrator, Lester, and Peter all then get one over on their boss/employer. The only exception is Neo, who takes the red pill and then, as far as we know, never thinks about his idiot boss again. (Neo is a true role model.)
